column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Tchibanga
#Text=Tchibanga is a city in Gabon .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Bush taxis will take you south from Libreville .
#Text=Catch a taxi for Tchibanga early in the morning - the trip can take over 12 hours .
#Text=Bring water , toilet paper and snacks , and ask to sit in the cabin of the truck , preferably in the passenger seat .
#Text=The drive down is an experience in itself .
#Text=There is also an airport in Tchibanga , though it is really little more than an air strip .
#Text=Flights are extremely unreliable and can be dangerous .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Tchibanga is small and most places are within walking distance .
#Text=You can rent a white and green city taxi for 100CFA or thereabouts to take you across town .
#Text=See
#Text=There is not much to see , though the surrounding countryside is pretty and very good for mountain biking ; the hills surrounding the city provide very pretty scenery .
#Text=The Nyanga river is also lovely , particularly at sunset .
#Text=You will have to bring your own bike down from Libreville , however .
#Text=Ask in town if there are any local Bwiti ( anamist ) religious ceremonies being held at night that can be viewed by foreigners .
#Text=If you are lucky , a traditional Bwiti ceremony is well worth seeing .
#Text=Most start at midnight and you can usually find them if you follow the sound of drumming ( bring a flashlight - you do n't want to step on a black mamba snake ! . )
#Text=Some ceremonies are closed to outsiders , but many will allow you to watch from benches on the outskirts and take photos .
#Text=Bwiti involves the taking of a native hallucinogenic drug called Iboga combined with ceremonial dancing and drumming .
#Text=Often the ceremony will be led by a local Nganga , or witch doctor , who will wear a costume of raffia and red , white and black paint .
#Text=The Nganga may carry a fetish made from a power animal , such as the tail of a civet cat .
#Text=Particularly interesting are the initiation ceremonies , where young people dress in white , red and black robes , take Iboga for the first time and voyage to see their ancestors .
#Text=There will most likely be a drunk papa at the ceremony who will be happy to explain the details .
#Text=Do
#Text=Walking or biking in the low , grassy hills surrounding the town is probably the best thing to do in Tchibanga .
#Text=The town also has a small market with friendly mamas selling veggies , fruits , bushmeat and , sometimes , monkey .
#Text=You can also wander down to the river and hire a local to take you for a ride in a traditional pirogue , or dugout canoe .
#Text=Tchibanga , like most of Gabon , receives almost no tourists , but the locals are friendly and will be happy to show you the best of their town .
#Text=Feel free to take photos , but be warned that you can expect half the town to want to be in the pictures !
#Text=If you are there for a few days , it 's well worth hiring a papa to take you " en brosse . "
#Text=This will involve walking out into the jungle areas to check hunting traps and the like .
#Text=You should not wander into the jungle alone as you will without question get lost .
#Text=A papa can explain the various traps he uses and show you local plants and animals .
#Text=If you 're lucky , you may see monkeys or even chimps !
#Text=The area around Tchibanga is home to the most incredible population of snakes , most particularly , the black mamba .
#Text=Locals hate and fear this snake and it is extremely poisonous , though not as dangerous as other snakes as it is very afraid of humans and will not attack unless threatened .
#Text=Buy
#Text=There are local artisans who make pottery , including statues , and carved wooden masks .

#Text=Ask at the market - you will most likely have to travel some ways out of town to someone 's house , but it is well worth it as any mask you buy in Tchibanga will not be made for the tourist trade , but for local ceremonial use .
#Text=Sadly , the quality is not what it once was , so do n't expect to find museum quality pieces .
#Text=It is hoped that increased responsible tourism will restart the dying art of traditional mask-making in Gabon .
#Text=Eat
#Text=There is at least one or two little bushmeat restaurants operating in town .
#Text=Ask the locals where they are .
#Text=Make sure to try the baton de manioc , a speciality of the Punu region , and " sauce Nouembwe , " a tasty orange sauce made from palm nuts .
#Text=There is also a local " sauce chocolate , " which is not chocolate but instead made from a local plant .

column1: #Text=The food is unique and involves many meats , fruits and veggies you ca n't find anywhere else .
#Text=For more western fare , try one of the three or four hotels in town , which all have the standard , but tasty , menu of chicken , rice , fries and fried plantains .
#Text=Drink
#Text=Regab or Castel , of course !
#Text=Tchibanga is PACKED with street bars and even some food stalls grilling fish at night - mostly tilapia , but some meat kebabs and even chicken feet if you 're feeling brave .
#Text=Kebabs or tilapia with spicy red pepper sauce ( pimant ) are really good with your cold beer .
#Text=Some of the hotels in the center of town have nightclubs .
#Text=Try to avoid the fancy clubs in favor of the more local ones - it 's fun to watch the locals dance to their favorite Zook or Zaireois tunes .
#Text=I often wonder if " Premier Gao " is still #1 in the clubs !
#Text=The Tchibanga high school students are great dancers and will put you to shame .
#Text=It 's customary to put a CFA note on someone 's forehead when they 're doing a good job dancing .
#Text=Be forewarned that they love to watch foreigners embarrass themselves !
#Text=Sleep
#Text=There are three or four good cases de passage , or motels in town .
#Text=They are all centrally located and impossible to miss .
